children.value: In this mini-study, you will focus on a scenario most relevant to marine diatom communities and  mixed layers.
Open a spreadsheet, in which to tabulate and plot results.
In a convenient place in the spreadsheet, enter four column heading in a row: ‚Äús‚Äù, ‚ÄúT8‚Äù, ‚ÄúT10‚Äù, and ‚ÄúT16‚Äù.
These represent the cell size, and three mixing layer intervals to test.
Under ‚Äús‚Äù, enter three numbers in a column: 2.5, 7.17 and 12.5.
These represent the sizes of cells you will test.
on Binder, and generate the user interface with
Setting up diatom variants and mixed layer characteristics
section, use the following parameter choices:
- Set the number of size classes to $n_{sizes}=16$, to better reflect potential marine diatom diversity.
Set the mixed layer depth to

children.html: zm=100z_m=100zm‚Äã=100

children.value: , to reflect the relatively deep mixed layers in some marine habitats.
Set the number of cells to seed to

children.html: Ni=0.1N_i=0.1Ni‚Äã=0.1

children.value: This will be the ‚Äúsmall‚Äù initial number of cells to test whether a diatom variant can invade.
Setting mixing event intervals, and running the simulation
Set the number of intervals to

children.html: npers=128n_{pers}=128npers‚Äã=128

children.value: These parameters will apply to all the model runs in this Activity.
Part 1: Is a diatom variant an ESS?

children.label: Part 1: Is a diatom variant an ESS?

children.value: Choose a part of your spreadsheet in which to tabulate biovolume, and another part to tabulate nutrient concentration.
In the biovolume part of your spreadsheet, enter ‚Äús‚Äù into a cell, and under it enter the size of diatom you just simulated (2.5). This is the column for diatom size in your biovolume table.
Next to the ‚Äús‚Äù, enter ‚ÄúBV8‚Äù and below it enter the

children.html: BVBVBV
s=2.5s=2.5s=2.5

children.value: in the model output. This is the column for biovolume for each of the size classes you simulate. The ‚Äú8‚Äù in ‚ÄúBV8‚Äù is the mixing interval, which is still the default 8 days.

In the nutrient concentration part of your spreadsheet, enter ‚Äús‚Äù into a cell, and under it enter the size of diatom you just simulated (2.5). This is the column for diatom size in your nutrient concentration table.

Next to the ‚Äús‚Äù, enter ‚ÄúR8‚Äù and below it enter the averaged nutrient concentration value in the model output. This is the column for nutrient concentration  for each of the size classes you simulate. The ‚Äú8‚Äù in ‚ÄúR8‚Äù is the mixing interval, which is still the default 8 days.

children.html: tmixt_{mix}tmix‚Äã

children.value: to 16, in the textbox, and click

This restarts the simulation, but uses the new mixing interval of 16 days instead of the default 8 days.
When you restart the simulation, it will use the endpoint of the previous simulation as its initial condition.
Because the simulation is running for many mixing intervals, it will ‚Äúforget‚Äù these initial conditions just as it did in the original run.
To record this datum, enter ‚ÄúBV16‚Äù next to ‚ÄúBV8‚Äù, and enter the new

children.html: BVBVBV

children.value: value below it. Also, enter ‚ÄúR16‚Äù next to ‚ÄúR8‚Äù, and enter the new averaged nutrient concentration value below it.

children.value: and nutrient concentration data in your spreadsheet.
Pay particular attention to the plots in Figure 2, to assess whether the diatom population is periodic. If not, make a note of the results, but do not include it in your table.
When the tables are complete, make X-Y Scatter plots of the data using the spreadsheet‚Äôs Chart funtion.
The data are in columns, with the first column being the x-axis.

children.html: BVBVBV

children.value: The title of the nutrient concentration plot is ‚Äú1-spp variation of nutrient concentration‚Äù.
The legend indicates the mixing interval associated with each line.
Because the biovolume and nutrient concentration differences are so extreme, double click on the vertical axes and set the scales to ‚ÄúLogarithmic‚Äù.
This completes the data collection for Part 1 of this Activity.

The second part of this activity is a survey of biovolume and nutrient concentrations across a series of mixing event intervals, for a mixed diatom population that initially includes all the size classes.
Choose a part of your spreadsheet for a new table for biovolume and nutrient concentration data, or start a new one.
Start a column labeled ‚ÄúTmix‚Äù and fill out the column underneath by entering the sequence of mixing intervals to assess:

children.html: Tmix=8,16,32,64T_{mix} = 8, 16, 32, 64Tmix‚Äã=8,16,32,64

children.value: Next to ‚ÄúTmix‚Äù, enter a label for biovolume,

children.html: BVBVBV

children.value: , and a label for nutrient concentration,

children.html: RRR

children.value: Execute the three setup button clicks:
Continue the simulation, with repeated clicks on

, until the total biovolume does not change.
This means the diatom population is essentially periodic, though there may be remnants of diatom variants at tiny population numbers.
Enter the results for averaged biovolume and nutrient concentration under their respective columns, in the row for

children.html: Tmix=8T_{mix}=8Tmix‚Äã=8

children.value: Repeat steps 2-3, changing the mixing interval

children.html: TmixT_{mix}Tmix‚Äã

children.value: to 16, 32 and 64, and recording the results in the appropriate rows.

children.html: TmixT_{mix}Tmix‚Äã

children.value: on the horizontal axis, and total biovolume on the vertical axis.

children.html: TmixT_{mix}Tmix‚Äã

children.value: on the horizontal axis, and nutrient concentration on the vertical axis.
Label the axes of both plots.

children.html: BVBVBV

children.value: The title of the nutrient concentration plot is ‚ÄúMulti-spp variation of nutrient concentration‚Äù.
This completes the data collection for Part 2 of this Activity.
